The patient initially presented to for suicidal ideation. He subsequently developed shortness of breath and tachycardia, and was found to have bilateral pulmonary emboli. The patient's imaging was discussed with , who thought that the patient's IVC filter was malpositioned, so the patient was transferred to for evaluation. His apixaban was stopped and he was started on a heparin gtt in anticipate of this procedure. Of note, patient should be on lifelong anticoagulation given recurrent DVT/PE. However, he previously discontinued warfarin due to GI side effects and stopped DOAC due to issues with insurance. His hospital course at was complicated by episodes of atrial fibrillation with RVR that only occurred with exertion. He is not on any chronic rate control medications. Regarding his suicidal ideation, the patient reported ongoing SI but reported feeling safe in the hospital. Plan for inpatient psychiatry admission once he return to . The patient has history of alcohol abuse and exhibited mild withdrawal during his hospital stay, but CIWA was subsequently able to be discontinued. On arrival to , the patient reports that he feels well. He denies any shortness of breath at rest or with exertion, no chest pain, no palpitations. No fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation. He reports that he feels depressed and hopeless. Has a plan for suicide to take an overdose of pills and alcohol. He reports that he used to see a therapist and take medications for his depression, but due to insurance issues he was unable to do this any longer. He reports that he has no plans to harm himself while in the hospital, and would like to have this procedure done. He is amenable to an inpatient psychiatric admission after this. Past Medical History: History of DVT/PE Bipolar I disorder Alcohol use disorder syndrome Cirrhosis, presumed due to alcohol DMII, A1c 6.7 Atrial fibrillation Anemia Thrombocytopenia Social History: Family History: No family history of DVT/PE. Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. , You were transferred from due to pulmonary clots in your lungs and a poorly positioned filter in the large vessel feeding blood to your heart ("IVC Filter"). We removed the filter and started you on blood thinners (apixaban) and a medication to control your heart rate (metoprolol). It is very important to continue these medications, avoid alcohol, and get follow up with your primary care doctor and cardiologist. You were transferred back to inpatient psychiatric care after your stay here. Sincerely, Your Team Followup Instructions:
